text:
Situation A. Predicting Shapes Making One Cut

Some interesting shapes result when you cut prisms from different angles. Suppose you start with a rectangular prism like those shown below and make one cut in the directions indicated by the dashed lines. Answer the following questions for each prism.

  1. What are the shapes of the two resulting figures?
  2. What are the shapes of the faces of the figures?
  3. How many vertices, edges, and faces does each figure have?

Rectangle Prism 1:

The indicated horizontal cut will form two rectangular prisms.

Each will have 8 vertices, 12 edges, and 6 rectangular faces.

Rectangle Prism 2:

The indicated slat cut will form two trapezoidal prisms. That is, the base of each will be a trapezoid and the other faces rectangles.

Each part will have 8 vertices, 12 edges, and 6 faces.

(Note: In the image in the Student Edition, the bases are in the position we customarily expect for sides.)

Rectangle Prism 3:

The indicated vertical cut will form two trapezoidal prisms. That is, the top and bottom of each will be a trapezoid and the other faces rectangles.

Each part will have 8 vertices, 12 edges, and 6 faces.

(Note: This cut is really the same as the Rectangle Prism 2, but the starting figure is in a somewhat different position.)
